greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the number of divisors d of n such that d^k is not equal to n for any k >= 1.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: a(1) = 0, a(p) = 1, a(pq) = 3, a(pq...z) = 2^k-1, a(p^k) = k+1-A000005(k), for p, q = primes, k = natural numbers, pq...z = product of k (k > 2) distinct primes p, q, ..., z.
example: For n = 16, set of such divisors is {1, 8}; a(16) = 2.
mathematica: Table[DivisorSum[n, 1 &, If[# > 1, #^IntegerExponent[n, #], 1] != n &], {n, 100}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, May 27 2017 *)
program: (PARI) a(n) = if(n==1, return(0)); my(f=factor(n), g = f[1, 2]); for(i=2, matsize(f)[1], g=gcd(g, f[i, 2])); numdiv(n) - numdiv(g) \\ _David A. Corneth_, May 27 2017
results.author: _Jaroslav Krizek_, Dec 25 2010
